p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:01): Today I present the 16th report of the Petitions Committee for the 45th Parliament, together with 29 petitions and eight ministerial responses to petitions previously presented. I also present with this report a corrigendum to report No. 15, which was presented on 11 September 2017.

Petitions often reflect community concerns. This report, for example, contains six petitions on the same-sex marriage debate as well as two petitions regarding citizenship requirements for parliamentarians. We also continue to receive petitions on immigration matters, climate change and international affairs. Petitions about concerns unique to individuals also continue to arrive on a range of other matters as diverse as our country itself, from coalmines to fuel quality, from private health to national road rules. The issues are many and varied.

It's wonderful that so many Australians are interested in engaging with the House of Representatives via the Petitions Committee. The Petitions Committee provides an avenue for these people’s voices to be heard about things that matter to them. The House’s e-petitioning system has made it even easier for people to have their say electronically, and the committee’s inquiry into the e-petitions system has demonstrated this.

We have been surveying people about their experiences with the e-petitions system and, while there are some areas of concern, the results so far have shown it's working well and it's making it easier for people to put their concerns to their elected representatives. We've also received some valuable submissions from users of the system as well as from domestic and international jurisdictions letting us know what has worked in their e-petition system, what hasn’t and what lessons they've learnt. All of this evidence will give the committee some direction for its current inquiry on how to improve the e-petitions system and this will be incorporated into the committee’s report.
I will continue to provide updates to the House on the work of the Petitions Committee and the inquiry into e-petitions.
PETITIONS
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:03): I present the following petitions:
Climate Change

This petition of concerned people of the electorate of Sydney draws to the attention of the House the severe and urgent threat that climate change poses to the health, well-being and security of all people around the world, particularly our poorest and most vulnerable neighbours. We remind the House that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions are the highest per person among wealthy nations while our emissions reduction targets are among the weakest.

We therefore ask the House to do all in its power to protect communities in Australia and our region from the harmful impacts of climate change - such as more sever heat, extreme and unpredictable weather and rising seas by:
- committing to deeper and more urgent reductions of our greenhouse emissions;

- developing a plan to ensure Australia achieves zero net greenhouse emissions well before 2050, and supporting families and communities affected by the transition towards renewable energy and more sustainable land use;
-providing additional assistance to help our poorest neighbours adapt to the harmful impacts of climate change.
from 1482 citizens.
Climate Change

This petition of concerned people of the electorate of Goldstein draws to the attention of the House the severe and urgent threat that climate change poses to the health, well-being and security of all people around the world, particularly our poorest and most vulnerable neighbours. We remind the House that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions are the highest per person among wealthy nations while our emissions reduction targets are among the weakest.

We therefore ask the House to do all in its power to protect communities in Australia and our region from the harmful impacts of climate change - such as more sever heat, extreme and unpredictable weather and rising seas by:
- committing to deeper and more urgent reductions of our greenhouse emissions;

- developing a plan to ensure Australia achieves zero net greenhouse emissions well before 2050, and supporting families and communities affected by the transition towards renewable energy and more sustainable land use;
- providing additional assistance to help our poorest neighbours adapt to the harmful impacts of climate change.
from 75 citizens.
Mining

The petition of Certain Citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House: The potential impact on the Sydney water catchment area and on the Kangaloon Aquifer, underlying the Southern Highlands and villages and towns of Berrima, New Berrima, Medway, Bowral, Moss Vale, Exeter, Robertson, Mittagong, Bundanoon and Sutton Forest, of the first large scale underground coal mine proposed in the area by Hume Coal which is a Korean owned subsidiary of POSCO.

We therefore ask the House to: Examine the proposed coal mine and the effects it may have on groundwater, surface water, the Kangaloon aquifer and the Sydney Water Catchment, under the water trigger' powers givens the Minister under the Environmental Protection and Biodiversity Conservation (EPBC) Ac.
from 540 citizens.
Live Animal Exports

The petition of Townsville residents, tourists and visitors who object to the live export of cattle from Townsville draws to the attention of the House: the cruelty inherent in the live export trade as cattle transported overseas suffer during long distance transport by road and on ships, multiple loading and unloading, poor handling, and cruel slaughtering methods. The trade also exports local jobs overseas with a negative flow-on effect on the local economy. Finally we are concerned that the loading of live export ships at the port approximately 2km from the city centre has a negative impact on local residents and visitors to areas adjacent to the Port such as the Casino, Entertainment Centre, the CBD and Strand areas due to the stench coming from thousands of cattle in a hot environment

We therefore ask the House to: introduce legislation to end the live export trade and support alternatives which would be better for the animals and for local jobs and which would help make Townsville more attractive as a tourist destination and a city in which to live, work and invest.
from 1358 citizens.
Climate Change

This petition of concerned people of the electorate of Franklin draws to the attention of the House the severe and urgent threat that climate change poses to the health, well-being and security of all people around the world, particularly our poorest and most vulnerable neighbours. We remind the House that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions are the highest per person among wealthy nations while our emissions reduction targets are among the weakest.

We therefore ask the House to do all in its power to protect communities in Australia and our region from the harmful impacts of climate change - such as more sever heat, extreme and unpredictable weather and rising seas by:
- committing to deeper and more urgent reductions of our greenhouse emissions;

- developing a plan to ensure Australia achieves zero net greenhouse emissions well before 2050, and supporting families and communities affected by the transition towards renewable energy and more sustainable land use;
-providing additional assistance to help our poorest neighbours adapt to the harmful impacts of climate change.
from 132 citizens.
Climate Change

This petition of concerned people of the electorate of Mayo draws to the attention of the House the severe and urgent threat that climate change poses to the health, well-being and security of all people around the world, particularly our poorest and most vulnerable neighbours. We remind the House that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions are the highest per person among wealthy nations while our emissions reduction targets are among the weakest.

We therefore ask the House to do all in its power to protect communities in Australia and our region from the harmful impacts of climate change - such as more sever heat, extreme and unpredictable weather and rising seas by:
- committing to deeper and more urgent reductions of our greenhouse emissions;

- developing a plan to ensure Australia achieves zero net greenhouse emissions well before 2050, and supporting families and communities affected by the transition towards renewable energy and more sustainable land use;
-providing additional assistance to help our poorest neighbours adapt to the harmful impacts of climate change.
from 774 citizens.
Aviation

Aviation safety - In view of unexplained aircraft disappearances and disasters I believe that there should be mandatory drug and alcohol testing of pilots and their co-pilots on all domestic and international flights leaving Australia.

We the flying public of Australia respectfully request that in the interests of aviation safety, all pilots and their co-pilots have a mandatory alcohol and drug test in full view of the flying public at the waiting area prior to boarding the aircraft, the test should be carried out by a senior police officer who is independent of the airport authority.
from 9 citizens.
Fuel Quality Standards Act

Proposed phase out and prohibition of leaded fuel for historic and culturally significant motor vehicles. These vehicles are, in the main, considered as "specialist interest groups" and "hobby vehicles" and they fall into the limited use category, and account for a very small portion of total nationwide petrol usage. If leaded fuel is not to be available, these cars will disappear almost immediately from our roads and competition events. Apart from depriving members of the public the pleasure of seeing these vehicles in use, younger Australians and tourists will have no idea of this country’s rich and pioneering motoring heritage going back to the very beginnings of the industry around the turn of the twentieth century. On 6 December, 2002, The Hon David Kemp, then Minister for the Environment and Heritage, granted approval under section 13 of the Fuel Quality Standards Act, 2000, subject to the conditions specified in section 17 of that Act, to a number of ‘regulated persons’, to use a leaded petrol. Prior to the expiry of such approval (and thereafter on a regular uninterrupted basis) the Minister granted an extension.

We request the House to provide an extension of approval under section 13 of the Fuel Quality standards Act, 2000, subject to the conditions specified in section 17 of that Act or provide dispensation to preserve our motoring heritage and history.
from 1386 citizens.
Taxation

The Federal Government has applied a luxury/ sales tax to women's sanitary items; deeming them a "luxury". Ask any female member of parliament and they will tell you there is nothing luxurious about a period.

We therefore request that the Australian Federal Government divert all revenue from said tax to better fund women's health promotion campaigns, research into women's health issues, additional funding for women's centres/ family planning clinics, subsidies related to procedures focused on women's health (eg assisted reproductive technologies, the use of Botox for chronic pelvic pain etc.), better assistance for women's mental health outlets and so on. This is a sure way that women are guaranteed to see the full benefit of the money they are being taxed every month for having a uterus, as there is no equivalent tax for men in relation to men's health products, such as condoms and Viagra. Taxing on the basis of gender is unjust, and does nothing to promote equality and equity in our society. Using the "tampon tax" revenue in this way does not right the wrong, but it will make a difference to every woman in Australia.
from 51 citizens.
Marriage Equality

We the undersigned, are incredulous and embarrassed by the inability and unwillingness of our political representatives to act on such an uncontroversial issue as same-sex marriage. Especially because our wish is simply for Australia to catch up with other western democracies in this aspect. Our politicians seem stuck in their party politics and are unjustifiably impacting the personal lives of many Australians. We don't understand why the Liberal party thinks it isn't a good idea to hold a free vote in Parliament but thinks it is a good idea to ask the public to partake in a free vote plebiscite. We believe our politicians were elected to represent us, yet this particular decision is being deferred back to us.

We petition Parliament to not go ahead with the plebiscite. We ask Parliament to hold a free vote on same-sex marriage as early as practicable and before 1 January 2018. We inform the Australian parliament that from 1 January 2018 we the undersigned will proceed to recognise our fellow citizens who are in same-sex partnerships as lawfully married. We will do so in our personal as well as in our professional lives - meaning we will afford them the same privileges when we deal with them professionally as we do to straight married couples (be us lawyers, accountants, doctors, public servants etc). Parliament must keep up with the changing Australian reality and not play political games with the lives of the people that elected them.
from 12 citizens.
Marriage Equality

We wish to move this petition quickly and promptly to empower the government and the members to act on our behalf as elected, and to save the waste of time, money and political energy being taken up by something that the citizens largely feel is a foregone conclusion. We desire that the funds and time otherwise dedicated to the pending plebiscite be redirected for the common good of the nation.

We, the represented public, request that the house consider immediately and pass a motion enabling marriage equality across and between all genders of consenting adults in Australia and desist from plans for any form of plebiscite once this petition provides sufficient support for the house to act appropriately in this matter.
from 512 citizens.
Vietnam: Fishing Industry

Draws to the attention of the House: In April 2016, millions of tons of fish were found dead on the Vietnamese central coastline due to toxic waste discharged by Formosa Steel International, leading to one of the biggest environmental disaster in the region in recent times. After several months of denial, Formosa conceded responsibility. This catastrophe decimated the Vietnamese fishing industry, leading to countless job losses, profound health and environmental implication on humans, fauna, flora and surrounding ecosystems. How far, how wide and how long its impact is yet to be determined. The lack of response from the government lead to protests, and calls for action to assist victims, remedial action and accountability across the world.
We therefore ask the House to:
• Condemn such dirty tactics and smear campaigns by the Vietnamese government against the victims, the Catholic priests and Hoa Hao Buddhist followers;

• Undertake a comprehensive review, in consultation with the Vietnamese Community in Australia; on all aids commitments and other country-to-country arrangements, including the human rights dialogue committee.
• Request the Australian Embassy to undertake an active role in monitoring the treatment of religious leaders and practitioners in accordance with the Article 18 of the ICCPR*.
from 62 citizens.
Marriage Equality

The government is exercising its ability to circumvent parliament and hold a non-binding postal plebiscite through the mechanisms of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This will be a costly process which will under-represent the opinions of the young, the poor, the mentally ill, First Nations and other disenfranchised minorities in this country. A much less costly way to run this non-binding plebiscite/statistical information survey would be to allow people to opt out of postal vote and vote through an online function -- perhaps a smart device app or a web based option such as the my.gov.au website -- requiring only those who wish to vote through the post with the default option of a postal vote. These functions are sure to cost significantly less than the currently estimated $122 million which this non-binding postal plebiscite/survey will cost, as evidenced in the government's reasoning behind moving much of these services exclusively online, while greatly enhancing participation in the vote/survey.

We therefore ask the House to direct the Australian Bureau of Statistics to implement online functions with which to opt out of receiving a postal vote and allowing them to have their vote counted online. These online functions should mirror existing online functions provided by the government, including an online portal like the current my.gov.au website and smart device apps like those currently available for online government services for Centrelink Students, Job Seekers etc.
from 9 citizens.
Veterans
Currently there is there is no prescribed period within which a delegate is required to make a decision in relation to DVA claims

Petition Request: We therefore call on the House to request the Government to introduce the changes as outlined below to the appropriate Acts, specifically to all legislation for which the DVA are responsible for enacting, as follows…...

1. Within 6 weeks of an application for a claim being received at an office of the DVA in Australia, the Secretary shall (a) cause for a for a report to be prepared, and decision to be made, referring to the claimed condition/s; and (b) cause a copy of that decision/s and report to be served on the applicant.

2. That a maximum or two 28 day extensions be available to the delegate, provisional to the claimant being furnished a statement in writing setting out progress on material questions of fact, referring to the evidence or other material on which the delegate is basing his/her investigation (progress report).
3. That a maximum of an additional 1 week extension, be allowable to the 6 week limit in the preparation of the decision and report, for each additional condition claimed.
4. That should a new claim be made during the investigation of an existing claim, the report for the existing claim should not be served until the report for any new claim is completed.
5. That any delays, however caused by the claimant, be reasonable grounds for an extension, not exceeding to the length of the delay the claimant was responsible for causing.
from 172 citizens.
ANZUS Treaty

This petition voices the concerns of the Australian electorate with regard to the ANZUS treaty. We do not feel that this treaty should be considered binding when the leader of the United States is demonstrably unstable. We do not agree that the Australian Prime Minister has the right to declare that we are 'joined at the hip' to the US in the current political climate without full consultation and a majority vote in Parliament. We believe that the Prime Minister is exposing Australia unnecessarily to an attack from an equally unstable North Korea. This decision is not democratic.

We request that the House fully debate the terms of the ANZUS treaty. Specifically, whether it is advisable for Australia to be bound by a collective security agreement with a country that has a volatile leader who appears to lack insight into both diplomacy and global affairs.
from 16 citizens.
Marriage Equality

Our LGBTI friends are born that way just like those of us born opposite sex attracted. It is not a lifestyle choice. The lead time to holding a plebiscite/postal vote will increase the high probability of an increase in suicide and self-harm in same-sex individuals. My older same sex friends tell me that as they grew, matured, and became more comfortable with their own journey, they are better placed to withstand abusive comments and messages that would flourish. They are however concerned for their younger brothers and sisters. I am advised the abusive comments and messages that will increase in the lead up to a plebiscite/postal vote may have led them to choose suicide when emerging into adulthood. Their concern extends to the mental health of children raised in same sex families. It is a furphy that allowing same sex couples to enjoy marriage will lead to child abuse. Simply look at the rates of family violence and child abuse that abounds in marriages and opposite sex defacto relationships. There are many healthy children being raised in healthy same sex families already.

I ask this government to abandon their promise of a plebiscite. You have taken it to the parliament it did not pass; you have met your election promise. It is therefore acceptable to find a new way to take it to the parliament. I call on the government to allow a free vote for same sex marriage now.
from 84 citizens.
Martin, Mr Shane

Shane Martin, father of star AFL player Dustin Martin, should be granted permission to come to Australia from NZ to attend the Brownlow medal best player event that Dustin will be at. Shane was deported to NZ in December 2016 based on previous non-jailable offences & motorcycle gang membership. Dustin is an inspiration for adults and children alike as a role model, and deserves to have his father there.
Please grant Shane Martin, father of star AFL footballer Dustin Martin, permission to visit Australia from New Zealand to attend the Brownlow Medal count with Dustin.
from 1 citizen.
Qualifications of Members and Senators
Barnaby Joyce continues to sit in Parliament as Deputy Prime Minister while his position has been disqualified as outlined in Section 44.(i) of Constitution of Australia.
On behalf of the public of the Commonwealth of Australia, we request that Barnaby Joyce be removed immediately, and a by-election be held in the Seat of New England for his suitable replacement.
from 26 citizens.
Parliament House: Procedures

We draw to the attention of the House the impropriety of House Standing Order 38 requiring The Lord’s Prayer to be read aloud by the Speaker on taking the chair each day. This ritual does not accord with the spirit of our Constitution (§116) in relation to the imposing of religious observance, nor does it represent the beliefs of the Australian people as a whole.
We ask the House to remove these prayers from Standing Orders.
from 1153 citizens.
Medical Costs

Going to the Doctor is expensive. Going to a Specialist is just unaffordable. This is especially true in Regional Australia where there are no bulk billing Doctors and little competition and Doctors can charge what they like. Waiting rooms of Emergency Departments are over flowing with patients who could go to a GP if they could afford it. This is clogging up the Public system and stretching the already thin on the ground resources in the Emergency Departments. The Doctors and Nurses are run off their feet every shift. The Government needs to step up to the plate and make things easier for patients and let us swipe our Medicare cards at the surgery and only pay the difference. We then get to see the Doctor of our choice and build up a history.

Government to pay the Doctors direct upon patient swiping Medicare card at Surgery, then patient only paying the balance of the bill. As it stands at the moment we pay the full amount of the bill, our Medicare card is then swiped and the rebate is credited back to our bank account. A Specialist was going to charge me $450 and I was getting $250 back, I couldn't afford to pay $450 but could have managed the $200. I don't see how a Doctor could rort the system by swiping Medicare cards for direct payments as they were once going to used as "the Australia Card" as they are a secure card.
from 10 citizens.
Marriage Equality

In 2004, the Howard Government introduced Marriage Amendment Bill 2004 to amend the definition of "marriage" to prescribe that, "the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life". Prior to this amendment, there was no definition of "marriage" under the Act. Henceforth, the relationship of same-sex couples is no longer recognised on par with heterosexual "marriages," which has the probable likelihood of creating legal issues and inequitable consequences under the common law/judiciary system. This amendment violates Article 7 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights: "All are equal before the law and are entitled without any discrimination to equal protection of the law. All are entitled to equal protection against any discrimination in violation of this Declaration and against any incitement to such discrimination." It is also violates Article 26 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights: "All persons are equal before the law and are entitled without any discrimination to the equal protection of the law. In this respect, the law shall prohibit any discrimination and guarantee to all persons equal and effective protection against discrimination on any ground such as race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status."
We therefore ask the House to repeal the Marriage Amendment Act 2004, No.126, 2004.
from 11 citizens.
Qualifications of Members and Senators

Section 44 of the Constitution – disqualifies Any person who: is under any acknowledgment of allegiance, obedience, or adherence to a foreign power, or is a subject or a citizen or entitled to the rights or privileges of a subject or a citizen of a foreign power; or

1. I submit that Ms Julia Banks is a Disqualified Person as she is at the very least " entitled to the rights and privileges of a subject or a citizen of a foreign power. under the Constitution Sect 44 and beg that the Speaker of the House of Representatives and Members refer her case to the High Court of Australia sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns -for consideration. The people need to have faith in the Constitution and trust those serving them to prove who they claim to be.

2. I refer to Ms Banks Maiden Speech to Parliament and her admission of her late Father's and Mother's Ancestry. There could be no doubt from this about the entitlement of Ms Banks to claim Greek Citizenship as:

3..The Hellenic Republic (as is the official name of Greece) applies the rule of "jus sanguinis" (the principle of blood), according to which a person obtains the Hellenic citizenship if he/she is born to a Greek parent, irrespective of the place where he/she is born. Ms Banks father was Greek and her Mother was also Greek according to the Greek Constitution as none of them had renounced their citizenship or entitlement.
from 2 citizens.
Qualifications of Members and Senators

Section 44 of the Constitution – disqualifies Any person who: is under any acknowledgment of allegiance, obedience, or adherence to a foreign power, or is a subject or a citizen or entitled to the rights or privileges of a subject or a citizen of a foreign power

I request that Mr Jason Falinski MP be referred to the High Court sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns I submit that he is a :disqualified person under Section 44 being a Dual Citizen.. I refer to Mr Falinski's Maiden Speech to Parliament and his admissions of Ancestry of his Father's.. The Polish Constitution adheres to the principal of "Jus sanguinis" (Latin: right of blood) This principle of nationality law by which citizenship is not determined by place of birth but by having one or both parents who are citizens of the state. A child born to a Polish parent is a Polish citizen at birth. This applies whether the child is born in Poland or elsewhere.
3. Acquiring Australian citizenship in no way automatically rescinded his father’s Polish citizenship and is commonly known as the “Citizenship Trap”.

4. Polish law (including the Constitution) does not allow the government to revoke someone's citizenship. Renunciation of Polish citizenship requires a petition with extensive supporting documentation subject to the approval of the President of Poland. Administrative processing of the petition can take up to years and the President's decision is final and cannot be appealed in court.
from 1 citizen.
Health Care

draws to the attention of the House: To the private health insurance industry and as it is currently operating in the Australian market. Premium increases are discriminating on age and location ignoring extensive periods without claims. A government minister quoted increase approval makes for good coverage but is totally inconsistent of what the actual increases are. Confusing information on what is covered and clearly identifying hospitals and doctors working with a fund until a procedure is required. The horrendous waste of money in allowing health funds to offer free glasses each year along with other gifts to entice people to shift to a fund.

We therefore ask the House to: Consider legislation to limit the annual increase to the approved percentage quoted by the health minister. Stop deals between individual hospitals and doctors unless this is declared up front before signing over to a new fund. The expectation is that one has a choice of timing, Doctor, Anaesthetist and Hospital. Not when the time comes one is told this person/hospital is not working with that fund etc.
from 5 citizens.
Refugees
Asking that the house immediately halt the government's inhumane treatment of refugees and continual abuses of human rights towards this group of people.
Repeal the action to remove refugees from government supported housing and strip them of their fortnightly welfare payments.
from 19 citizens.
Roads
That the Federal Government submits for consideration by the Transport and Infrastructure Council an addition to the Australian Road Rules as documented below.

A national law is introduced that requires motorists travelling on a roadway to slow their vehicle to at least 40km/h, regardless of the posted speed limit, when they are approaching approved emergency vehicle/s that are either stopped or in motion, on or at the roadside, attending to an emergency incident provided the approved emergency vehicle/s have their emergency warning lights activated. Where possible, and if safe to do so, motorists must also change to any available adjacent lanes in the same direction to provide a safety buffer for the approved emergency vehicle/s and the emergency workers assigned to these vehicles whilst attending to these emergency incidents.
from 1 citizen.
Tuberculosis
Visitor visa application approval for persons with non contagious extra-pulmonary tuberculosis.

We ask the House to differentiate between contagious pulmonary and non contagious extra pulmonary tuberculosis when it comes to granting visitors visas for persons who are on current treatment, have clear radiographs and bloods and who are otherwise deemed to be in good health. At present the Medical Officer of the Commonwealth (MOC) does not distinguish between pulmonary and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis. Extra-pulmonary tuberculosis (EPTB) is not found in the lungs and is thus classified as not being contagious and poses no risk to the population. According to a publication found on http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/content/D140EDF48C0A0CEACA257 BF0001A3537/$File/TB-2.0-april2015.pdf, extra-pulmonary tuberculosis has a ‘negligible or none’ degree of infectiousness of the case and also states that there is ‘no restrictions on the movement of patients with extra-pulmonary disease, who have had pulmonary TB excluded or those with negative sputum smears on adequate therapy'. However the MOC states that they do not differentiate between the two types of tuberculosis. We ask the House to please review this as it deeply affects immigrants, permanent residents and citizens who have family living overseas and have chosen to make Australia their home. Many of us haven't seen our families for years and have special circumstances for wanting/needing family to be with us. Your consideration is greatly appreciated.
from 25 citizens.
Civil Liberty

Left wing hate groups are a threat to democracy, freedom and civil liberty. In recent years, these groups have started to act outside the realms of lawful, civil, peaceful protest employing the use of violence, racism, sexism, harassment, bullying and bigotry to advance their agendas of hate. Such groups include but are not limited to: ANTIFA, GetUp, Factions of the Greens ie. Leftist Renewal and Trade Unions ie. CFMEU. Hate speech is not a civil liberty or fundamental freedom protected by the Australian constitution and therefore shouldn't be treated as such. Left wing hate speech therefore needs to be taken seriously and dealt with accordingly to ensure continued community cohesion and maintaining the peace.
We therefore ask the house to act and take action on this issue by considering and legislating the following.
1. Have all the groups listed above and others found to be like them listed as terrorist organizations and use Australia's existing anti terrorism legislation to shut them down.

2. Any individual, organization or political party found to be financially backing such groups needs to be tried with treason and if they are a political party, their party status be removed and their elected members impeached from office if applicable.
3. All people, parties or organizations found to be guilty of left wing hate be made to issue a public apology to the people of Australia.
from 48 citizens.
Advertising
These advertisements are discriminatory and harmful to Australian LGBTIQA+ citizens and are in breach of community standards.

We therefore ask the House to review federal advertising legislation to include political advertising under the following: "Ads cannot vilify or discriminate against people based on their sexual preference (or race, gender and other factors). Misleading or deceptive messages are also prohibited. Political ads, however, are exempt from all of these limitations." (Sydney Morning Herald, 20 August 2017). We furthermore ask the House to ban all discriminatory anti marriage equality television and print advertising conducted in 2017. In particular, we ask the house to review the content of the television advertisement by the Coalition for Marriage which aired on Channel 9 in August 2017 ("You Can Say No" campaign).
from 39 citizens.
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:03): I present the following ministerial responses to petitions previously presented.
Australian Classification Board
Dear Mr Vasta

Thank you for your letter of 22 May 2017 about petition EN0165 regarding the powers of the Australian Classification Board (the Board) and the request from petitioners to reform some aspects of the National Classification Scheme. I am writing to you in response to this petition.

The National Classification Scheme is a co-operative scheme established between the Commonwealth and all state and territory governments. The Commonwealth is responsible for making classification decisions and state and territory governments are responsible for regulating the sale, exhibition and advertising of classified material.

Under Section 9 of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 (the Classification Act), the Board must apply the National Classification Code and the Classification Guidelines (the Code and the Guidelines), which are available at www.classification.gov.au/About/Pages/Legislation.aspx. The Code and the Guidelines are agreed by the Commonwealth and the states and territories.

The Code states that classification decisions are to give effect as far as possible to the principle that adults should be able to read, hear and see what they want. It also states that minors should be protected from material likely to harm them, and that all Australians should be protected from offensive unsolicited material. It also states the need to take account of community concerns about depictions that condone or incite violence, particularly sexual violence, and the portrayal of persons in a demeaning manner.

The Refused Classification (RC) category is designed to prevent children and the community from being exposed to very high impact content such as material that promotes terrorism, crime and violence (including sexual violence) and child exploitation material. The Board can only refuse to classify content in very specific circumstances that are outlined in the Code and the Guidelines.
The RC category, as outlined in the Code, relates to content that:

describes, depicts, expresses or otherwise deals with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in such a way that they offend against the standards of morality, decency and propriety generally accepted by reasonable adults to the extent that they should not be classified; or
describes or depicts in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, a person who is, or appears to be, a child under 18 (whether the person is engaged in sexual activity or not); or
promotes, incites or instructs in matters of crime or violence.
Publications, films or computer games that advocate the doing of a terrorist act must also be classified RC under section 9A of the Classification Act.

When making classification decisions, the Board seeks to reflect current community standards and takes note of comments and views expressed in correspondence received. RC decisions for commercial films and computer games have constituted less than half a percent of decisions made by the Board over the last five years. Only two computer games were classified RC by the Board in the 2016-2017 financial year.

The Department of Communications and the Arts (the Department) also regularly undertakes research with members of the community to help guide policy development and provide feedback to the Board. Research includes work on whether the Code and the Guidelines align with community expectations. More information on community research is available on the classification website at www.classification.gov.au/Public/Resources/Pages/Other%20Resources/Research­documents.aspx.

The Department is working with states and territories on ways to modernise the National Classification Scheme in light of technological and industry changes. This includes examining the scope of the RC category and whether it continues to reflect Australian community standards. Any future changes to the Code and the Guidelines or changes to the Classification Board's powers must be agreed to by the Commonwealth and the states and territories.

span.span: Establishing a Restricted (X18+) rating for computer games

p.span: The Code and the Guidelines were most recently changed in 2013 to introduce the R18+ category for computer games. This reform was driven directly in response to feedback from the gaming community.

My Department regularly consults with the games industry and the adult industry, who have not identified a need for an X18+ category for computer games. Research with the community and correspondence to the Department and the Board from members of the community also have not suggested a need for an X18+ category for computer games. However, in working with the states and territories on ways to modernise the National Classification Scheme, my Department will examine the XI 8+ category. As previously mentioned, any future changes to the Code and the Guidelines must be agreed to by the Commonwealth and the states and territories.

The costs of the Board classifying material, including administrative support by the Department, are largely recovered through classification fees. Under the Classification Act, classification applications must be accompanied by the prescribed fee set in the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Regulations 2005. The fee framework must adhere to the Australian Government Cost Recovery Guidelines, administered by the Department of Finance.
For more information, the Cost Recovery Impact Statement — Classification Fees document is available on the Classification website at

Following the recommendations in the Australian Law Reform Commission's review Classification — Content Regulation and Convergent Media, the Government has changed laws to cut red tape for game developers and the film industry. These include:

InDecember 2016, Commonwealth, state and territory classification Ministers agreed to the ongoing use of the International Age Rating Coalition (IARC) classification tool for online and mobile computer games on participating storefronts, including Google Play, Nintendo, Microsoft and Sony. Game developers complete an online questionnaire about content in the game and the IARC tool generates an Australian rating and consumer advice for free. Over 800,000 online and mobile games have been classified, all at no cost to game developers.

In July 2015, the Government changed laws regarding the modification of films and computer games. Many kinds of modifications can be made to films or computer games without the need to submit them for classification again. For example, the following changes can be made to a computer game without affecting the original classification:
Additions of songs, characters, weapons, costumes, skins or vehicles.
Additions of environments, levels, missions, storylines or modes.
Graphic enhancements.
Format changes.

In September 2015, the Government introduced new classification exemption arrangements for special events (such as film festivals and computer game expos like PAX Australia and Supanova) and for cultural institutions wishing to exhibit unclassified films, computer games and certain publications. Event organisers can self-assess their eligibility for exemption from classification, rather than seeking an exemption from the Director of the Classification Board. These changes have enabled a faster and simpler process for showing unclassified computer games at expos at no cost to the event organisers.

The Authorised Assessor Scheme for Computer Games is another initiative to reduce classification fees to the computer game industry. The Scheme enables those in the computer game industry to be trained to recommend the classification and consumer advice for a computer game to the Director of the Classification Board. Applications that include a recommendation from an authorised industry assessor require a lower classification fee.

Another recent development is that in December 2016, the Government announced a 12 month pilot of a classification tool for Netflix. Film and TV series content on Netflix can be classified for Australian audiences more easily and quickly.

In addition, a wide range of films and computer games are exempt entirely from classification under section 6B of the Classification Act including documentaries of sporting events and computer games of an educational or professional nature. Furthermore, the Classification Act provides for full or partial fee waivers for eligible applicants under specific circumstances - for example, where it is in the public interest to do so for public health or educational reasons.

For computer games that involve a classification fee, Australian classification fees are competitive compared to those in similar overseas jurisdictions. Unlike some other countries, Australian classifications apply to a game across all platforms, both boxed and online. Games classified G, PG or M by the Board have effect in New Zealand where they are cross-rated.

The Department regularly works together with the games industry peak body, the Interactive Gaines and Entertainment Association (IGEA), and games developers to consider how to make the classification process more efficient and innovative. The Department's work on modernising the National Classification Scheme will consider ways to provide classification information to Australians as quickly and cheaply as possible for industry.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information will be of assistance in responding to the petitioners.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Mr Fifield
Suicide
Dear Mr Vasta

Thank you for your correspondence of 22 May 2017 to the Attorney-General, Senator the Hon George Brandis QC, concerning petition number EN0168. The petition requests new laws to criminalise individuals for encouraging suicide in Australia. Your letter has been forwarded to me for reply as I have portfolio responsibility for criminal law issues.

Under Australia's federal system of government, the Commonwealth, states and territories have different areas of responsibility. Criminal law enforcement is primarily a matter for the states and territories, with each managing their own criminal justice system.

States and territories are generally responsible for criminal offences in relation to conduct of this nature. I note that it appears that each state and territory has some variation of a law criminalising the encouragement of suicide.

For example, in South Australia it is an offence for a person to aid, abet or counsel the suicide or attempted suicide of another person under section 13A(5) of the Criminal Law Consolidation Act 1935 (SA). Similarly, in the Northern Territory it is an offence to assist or encourage another person to commit or attempt to commit suicide under section 162 of the Criminal Code Act 1983 (NT).
For further reference, please see the included list for the location of each state and territory's laws against the encouragement of suicide.
ACT Section 17 of the Crimes Act 1900 (ACT)
NSW Section 31C of the Crimes Act 1900 (NSW)
NT Section 162 of the Criminal Code Act 1983 (NT)
QLD Section 311 of the Criminal Code Act 1899 (QLD)
SA Section 13A(5) of the Criminal Law Consolidation Act 1935 (SA)
TAS Section 163 of the Criminal Code Act 1924 (Tas)
VIC Section 6B of the Crimes Act 1958 (Vic)
WA Section 288 of the Criminal Code Act Compilation Act 1913 (WA)
In addition, at a federal level there are also laws relating to the encouragement of suicide.

Under the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Cth), it is an offence to use a carriage service (such as the internet) to distribute or access suicide-related material with the intention or inciting suicide, or to provide instruction on a particular method of committing suicide. The maximum penalty for this offence is a fine of $210,000 for individuals or $1,050,000 for corporate bodies.
Thank you for forwarding on this petition. I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Justice, Mr Keenan
Australian Citizenship
Dear Ms Wicks
I refer to correspondence from Mr Ross Vasta MP of 20 June 2017 enclosing Petition EN0195, concerning the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship.

The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship.
The package of reforms includes:
increasing the general residence requirement;
introducing an English language test;
strengthening the Australian values statement;
strengthening the test for Australian citizenship;
introducing a requirement for applicants to demonstrate their integration into the Australian community; and
strengthening the pledge.
I note the concerns raised in the Petition about the increased general residence requirement, and the introduction of an English language test.

Applicants will need to be a permanent resident in Australia for a period of four years immediately prior to their application for citizenship, during which time applicants may be absent from Australia for no more than 12 months in total.

Changing the length of the qualifying period of permanent residency will allow more time for the Government to assess all applicants' experience of integrating into life in Australia. Internationally, four years is at the lower end of residency requirements. Some countries, such as Denmark, require nine years continuous residence before a person can apply for citizenship.
Other countries having residence requirements for citizenship through naturalisation include:
the United States of America requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years permanent residence;
the United Kingdom requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years residence; and
Germany requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least eight years residence.

It should be noted that the Special Residence and Defence Service requirements currently included in the Australian Citizenship Act 2007 will remain unchanged, as will the Ministerial discretion to in effect waive the permanent residence requirements if the Minister is satisfied that the person will suffer significant hardship or disadvantage because of not meeting the requirements. The person still has to be present in Australia during the relevant period, however they may be here on a temporary visa.

Further, the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment (Strengthening the Requirements for Australian Citizenship and Other Measures) Bill 2017 provides the Minister with a personal, non-compellable power to waive the general residence requirement where the Minister is satisfied that it is in the public interest to do so.

The reforms will also introduce a separate stand-alone English test for aspiring citizens by conferral, which will require applicants to achieve a minimum level of `competent'. A competent level of English means a generally effective command of the language despite some inaccuracies, inappropriate usage and misunderstandings; fairly complex language is used and understood, particularly in familiar situations. English language proficiency is essential for economic participation, social cohesion and integration into the Australian community.

The Department of Immigration and Border Protection currently accepts English language test scores from the following test providers as evidence of English language proficiency for the purposes of migration under the Migration Act 1958:
International English Language Testing System (IELTS);
Occupational English Test (OET);
Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL);
Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic; and
Cambridge English: Advanced (CAE).
IELTS offer a General or Academic test. The Academic test is not required for migration purposes, however, the Department accepts either as evidence of English proficiency.

Usually people applying for higher education or professional registration take the Academic test and those who are applying for secondary education, work experience or training programmes take the General Training test.
Exemptions from the English language test will apply for those applicants who:
have a permanent or enduring physical or mental incapacity;
are aged 60 or over, or have a hearing, speech or sight impairment;
are aged under 16; or
applied under the born in Papua; born to a former Australian citizen; or statelessness provisions.

Limited exemptions will apply for citizens of the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada, New Zealand or the Republic of Ireland who hold a passport for that country when they apply for citizenship, and applicants who have undertaken specified English language studies at a recognised Australian education institution. This is consistent with the Department's current approach to determining competent English for skilled visas.
All applications received on or after 20 April 2017 will be affected by the changes.
Further information on Australian citizenship, including details on the reforms, can be found at: http://www.bordergov.aufTrav/Citi.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton
Australian Citizenship
Dear Ms Wicks
I refer to correspondence from Mr Ross Vasta MP of 20 June 2017 enclosing Petition EN0196, concerning the Australian Government's reforms to strengthen the requirements for Australian citizenship.

The package of reforms announced by the Prime Minister on 20 April 2017 is the Government's response to the National Consultation on Citizenship, which indicated strong support for strengthening the requirements for Australian citizenship.
The package of reforms includes:
increasing the general residence requirement;
introducing an English language test;
strengthening the Australian values statement;
strengthening the test for Australian citizenship;
introducing a requirement for applicants to demonstrate their integration into the Australian community; and
strengthening the pledge.
All applications received on or after 20 April 2017 will be affected by the changes.
I note concerns raised in the Petition about the increased general residence requirement.

Applicants will need to be a permanent resident in Australia for a period of four years immediately prior to their application for citizenship, during which time applicants may be absent from Australia for no more than 12 months in total.

Changing the length of the qualifying period of permanent residency will allow more time for the Government to assess all applicants' experience of integrating into life in Australia. Internationally, four years is at the lower end of residency requirements. Some countries, such as Denmark, require nine years continuous residence before a person can apply for citizenship.
Other countries having residence requirements for citizenship through naturalisation include:
the United States of America requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years permanent residence;
the United Kingdom requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least five years residence; and
Germany requires eligible applicants to demonstrate at least eight years residence.

It should be noted that the Special Residence and Defence Service requirements currently included in the Australian Citizenship Act 2007 will remain unchanged, as will the Ministerial discretion to in effect waive the permanent residence requirements if the Minister is satisfied that the person will suffer significant hardship or disadvantage because of not meeting the requirements. The person still has to be present in Australia during the relevant period, however they may be here on a temporary visa.

Further, the Australian Citizenship Legislation Amendment (Strengthening the Requirements for Australian Citizenship and Other Measures) Bill 2017 provides the Minister with a personal, non-compellable power to waive the general residence requirement where the Minister is satisfied that it is in the public interest to do so.

The Australian public expects aspiring citizens to commit to Australia and Australian values, and the Government has determined that four years is an appropriate period over which to measure this commitment.
The Government intends that all applications received on or after 20 April 2017 will be affected by the reforms announced on that date.
Further information on Australian citizenship, including details on the reforms, can be found at: http://www.border.gov.au/Trav/Citi.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, Mr Dutton
Falun Gong
Dear Ms Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 regarding Petition EN0219 calling for the release of the mother and sister of Ms Lorrita Liu from detention in China.

The treatment described in the petition of Ms Liu's mother and sister is of concern. The Agreement on Consular Relations between Australia and the People's Republic of China allows for Australian citizens, who enter China on a valid Australian travel document, to be visited by Australian Consular officials and afforded consular protection. To assist in determining if we are able to provide consular assistance, can you please confirm if Yuhua Li and Chunxia Liu are Australian citizens?

Chinese authorities are under no obligation to cooperate if Ms Li and Ms Liu are not Australian citizens. Consular assistance is limited to Australian citizens as outlined in our Consular Services Charter (see smartraveller.gov.au).

China's ban on Falun Gong and its treatment of practitioners breach international human rights standards. The Australian Government regularly raises our human rights concerns with China. Subject to the provision of further details on the citizenship of Ms Liu's relatives, Australian officials will identify an opportunity to raise their cases.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop
Discrimination
Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 regarding petition number EN0236 calling for the equal treatment of all Australians.

The Australian Government believes all people are entitled to respect, dignity and the opportunity to participate in society regardless of their personal attributes, and recognises that to enjoy human rights on an equal basis with others, people need to be able to do so free from discrimination. Australia's federal Racial Discrimination Act protects people from discrimination on the grounds of race, colour, descent, or national or ethnic origin in any field of public life, including education, employment, health and social security.

The Racial Discrimination Act allows the use of affirmative action by allowing 'special measures' to achieve substantive equality between different racial or ethnic groups including between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. These measures include measures to ensure that minority racial groups are guaranteed the equal enjoyment or exercise of human rights and fundamental freedoms, and do not constitute unlawful discrimination under the Racial Discrimination Act.
Thank you again for writing on this matter.
Yours faithfully
from the Attorney General, Mr Brandis
Elder Abuse
Dear Ms Wicks
Thank you for your representations of 16 August 2017 regarding a petition seeking a national Royal Commission into Elder Abuse to investigate the quality of aged care in Australia (EN0243).

I too was shocked and concerned to hear about the mistreatment of people at the Oakden Older Persons Mental Health Service in South Australia, which is why the Turnbull government commissioned an independent review of national aged care quality regulatory processes.

The Review is being led by Kate Carnell AO, a veteran public administrator, in conjunction with Professor Ron Paterson, an international expert on patients' rights, complaints, health care quality and the regulation of healthcare professions.

The Review panel is looking at any gaps or deficiencies in the Commonwealth's aged care regulatory system, including accreditation, monitoring, investigation, complaints and compliance. Their report is due to me on 29 September 2017.

In addition, in June 2017, the Senate Community Affairs References Committee (the Committee) commenced an inquiry into the effectiveness of the aged care quality assessment and accreditation framework for protecting residents from abuse and poor practices, and ensuring proper clinical and medical care standards are maintained and practised. its report is due in February 2018.

I note the petition also refers to the Royal Commission investigating the ability of aged care sector to meet the increasing demand for qualified carer and clinical workforce. It is estimated the aged care sector will need to expand its workforce from 366,000 to 980,000 by 2050, to respond to demand from population ageing. The 2017-18Federal Budget announced the establishment of an aged care industry-led taskforce to explore short, medium and longer term options to boost supply, address demand and improve productivity for the aged care workforce.

In June 2017, the Committee tabled its report on the 'Future of Australia's aged care sector workforce'. The government is considering the Committee's recommendations in the context of the aged care workforce strategy, and will table a response in due course.

Finally, as part of the changes to aged care announced in 2012, a comprehensive review was included in the Aged Care (Living Longer Living Better) Act 2013 (the Act). One of nine matters required to be considered, was the effectiveness of workforce strategies in aged care services.

On 31 July 2017, Mr David Tune AO PSM, the independent reviewer, provided me with his report. As required under legislation, I will table the report in each house of parliament by no later than 14 September 2017. Once the report is tabled, it will be made available at agedcare.health.gov.au/reform/aged-care-legislated-review.

The health, safety and wellbeing of older people who reside in aged care services are of paramount importance to the Australian Government. However, in light of the four separate, but interrelated reviews, I do not support the call for a Royal Commission into Elder Abuse, until the government has fully considered the recommendations from all of the above reviews and inquiries.
Thank you for raising this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Aged Care, Mr Wyatt
Falun Gong
Dear Ms Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 15 August 2017, drawing my attention to a petition submitted to the Standing Committee on Petitions calling for an immediate end to the persecution of Falun Gong in China (Petition number: PN0064).
The Australian Government agrees that China's ban on Falun Gong and its treatment of practitioners are in breach of international human rights standards.

We are aware of claims of illegal organ harvesting in China from Falun Gong practitioners. Those claims, if true, would be deeply disturbing. While we consider that there is insufficient credible evidence to support the Falun Gong-specific allegations, there is little doubt that organs have been harvested from executed prisoners for use in medical transplants, at least prior to 2015. Australia strongly opposes this practice.

In 2015, Dr Huang Jiefu, head of China's organ donation committee, announced that only voluntarily donated organs from civilians could be used in transplants from 1 July 2015. While this announcement was welcome, we recognise that it will make little difference if it is not properly enforced.

We have raised our concerns over the practice of harvesting organs from executed prisoners directly with the Chinese Government. We will continue to urge China to ensure the 2015 regulations are fully implemented at all levels.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop
BUSINESS
Rearrangement
Mr WILKIE (Denison) (10:03): At the request of the member for Melbourne, I fix Monday, 23 October as the day for presenting the Coal-Fired Power Funding Prohibition Bill 2017.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Renewable Energy Legislation Amendment (Supporting Renewable Communities) Bill 2017

p.span: Renewable Energy Legislation Amendment (Supporting Renewable Communities) Bill 2017
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms McGowan.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Ms McGOWAN (Indi) (10:05): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Across Australia, in the media and in this House, we know we've got a problem with energy. We've got a problem with the price of energy. We've got a huge problem in rural and regional communities, in particular with manufacturing in communities, with prices going up. We know that the Prime Minister is working on the big picture, but I reckon there's a really important part of this whole infrastructure, an important part of the jigsaw, that would make a really big difference, and that's support for community energy. It's part of the answer. To date, I'd say we've been working at the global picture of energy prices and we haven't paid nearly enough attention to the role of communities and local governments in addressing this problem. The Renewable Energy Legislation Amendment (Supporting Renewable Communities) Bill 2017 is part of the solution. The bill is particularly directed to the work of ARENA, and I will talk in a minute about how that can happen, but it is the opportunity to actually make community energy a really central part of resolving the problems that we're facing.

The bill that I'm proposing provides greater certainty to communities looking to develop a community energy based model. It encourages innovation and investment and aims to ensure best practice planning to support growth in community energy. The bill will give certainty to a sector that is still developing so that, while programs may come and go and governments may come and go, their industry will remain part of the conversation at ARENA and CEFC. The bill amends the functions of ARENA to allow for funding of planning, development or implementation of community energy projects, and development by the community energy sector of innovative businesses and financing models. It clarifies ARENA's role in collecting, analysing, interpreting and disseminating information and knowledge on community energy models and in advising the minister on these matters. The bill also makes additions to the functions of the CEFC to allow investments in community joint partnerships or other community energy models to support sector development. The bill defines a clear role for the CEFC in supporting and accelerating the commercial viability and self-sustainability of community energy projects. Recognising that ARENA and CEFC both play a role in supporting community energy is reflective of the original intent of these organisations when they were established in 2012. The supporting renewable energy communities package brings together the ARENA Act and the CEFC Act once again.

Mr Speaker, I will now talk to some of the detail of this. Really and truly, communities in my electorate of Indi—as I'm sure they are in your electorate of Casey—are absolutely taking the run with solving the problems of their own energy costs. I am really proud that in my electorate not only have communities, like Yackandandah, got together but councils are working together. Indigo, Benalla, Winton Wetlands, Renewable Albury Wodonga Energy, Totally Renewable Yackandandah, Benalla Sustainable Future Group, Up2Us Landcare Alliance in Mansfield, the Wangaratta Sustainability Network, the Murrindindi Climate Network, North East Water—playing a leadership role—and Wodonga Albury Towards Climate Health are among many groups establishing strong working relationships with local and state government and industry groups to develop their own solutions. These include supply based projects like renewable energy installations and storage as well as demand-side projects like energy efficiency, demand management and community education. We are working on both sides of the supply and demand equation, which we know is so important because this is an economic problem that we're facing.

One of the most ambitious and successful projects to date, which I've talked about often in this House, is Totally Renewable Yackandandah. TRY, as they're affectionately known, are actively working towards their goal of 100 per cent renewable energy and energy sovereignty by 2022 by introducing energy measures to reduce the total amount of energy the town consumes and increase the amount of renewable energy generated by the town through the installation of solar systems.

To support this, they have established the TRY Perpetual Energy Fund. This local community has its own philanthropic fund; it has raised money; and it reinvests for community energy in Yackandandah. They provide no-interest loans for energy efficient or solar installations. This perpetual energy fund has supported the installation of large solar panels on an array of community assets, including the Yackandandah Community Development Company, which is a community-owned and operated fuel station and farm produce store, and also the supermarket, the hospital, the men's shed, the community centre and the Yackandandah Folk Festival. TRY are now working on a business plan that will refine the community energy model.

This innovative approach has the potential to be replicated right across regional communities, helping to boost regional Australia. Herein lies the role for the Commonwealth. Today in my electorate we have local communities doing extraordinarily good work taking the run. We have local government providing support and infrastructure and employment opportunities. We have the state government absolutely coming to the party putting money in. The gap is the Commonwealth. While the Commonwealth is working on energy, I believe that if we could bring the Commonwealth to state government, to local government and to this community sector, we would have the trifecta working and unleash the power that our rural communities have to really and truly develop sustainable and reliable energy systems.

Of course we need a national approach and a national policy. But the community energy sector is one really important part of the jigsaw. What I am proposing today is that we bring ARENA to the table. You would ask: why hasn't ARENA been there in the past? It sounds so obvious. Initially they did. When ARENA was set up under the previous government, they did do a bit of work with community-based power. I understand through anecdotal evidence that it didn't work out so well. The industry has really matured now, and it's time for another approach. I would be saying to ARENA, and to the government, energy is like an elephant. The joke goes around, 'How do you eat an elephant?' The answer is, 'One piece at a time'. I'm saying that with community energy we can just bite off one part of the big elephant and really make it work.

I say to ARENA, come and work with us in Indi and with my colleagues in other places. I see here my National Party colleagues from Mallee and Murray. I know they have enormous amounts of sun and huge communities who want to do this as well. Come and work with us rural communities and help us work out where the regulatory barriers are. Help us work out how to do the governance models and set up the pricing so we can get these grids happening locally.

I have to say to my colleagues, in Yackandandah we have a good partnership going with AusNet Services. AusNet Services are putting in the infrastructure; the Victoria government is putting in money; local government is putting in money. We're ready to go. The opportunity for the nation is huge. It's going to take real skill for ARENA to work across the governments, because traditionally that's the hard thing. But I'm really optimistic because I've seen government projects such as the City Deals, where we've been able to work with Commonwealth, state, local and with community groups. I know that we've just had a review of Regional Development Australia and how RDAs work. I would be saying to ARENA and other CFCs, 'Come and work with our Regional Development Australia group and Regional Development Victoria, because together we could actually get this integration happening and really get terrific runs on the ground.

I want to finish off with a message to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, I know you care about innovation. Your National Innovation and Science Agenda gives great hope to so many people in Australia. What I'm saying with this particular bill is that it doesn't actually need make-up stuff. We don't have to conjure magic out of the ether. We already have innovation happening in our communities. We already have job creation happening. We already have community involvement, state government involvement and local government involvement. We are on the cusp of the innovation that we know is going to make such a difference to our regional communities. It will create jobs; it will employ people; it will help solve the high price of energy; and in the process it will build sustainability and confidence in our communities.

So, I'm really pleased to bring this bill to the House. I look forward to the government encouraging them to bring it on for debate so that we can actually have a fair dinkum debate in the House and my colleagues from the government side, particularly the rural and regional Libs and Nats, can say, 'Yep: this is a great program, and it would make a huge difference to our communities, and they'd be willing to support it.' I'm very happy to commend this bill to the House.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Mr Wilkie: I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.
Debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Competition and Consumer Legislation Amendment (Small Business Access to Justice) Bill 2017

p.span: Competition and Consumer Legislation Amendment (Small Business Access to Justice) Bill 2017
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Dr Leigh.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Dr LEIGH (Fenner) (10:15): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.

The Australian economy is excessively concentrated in many sectors. In department stores, newspapers, banking, health insurance, supermarkets, domestic airlines, internet service providers, baby food and soft drinks, the biggest four firms control more than four-fifths of the market. In petrol retailing, telecommunications, credit unions, cinemas, liquor retailing, bottled water and fruit juice, the largest four firms control more than two-thirds of the market. In pharmacies, pharmaceuticals, hardware, gyms, snack food, magazines, newsagents and international agencies, the big four firms account for more than half of the market. If you apply the notion that a concentrated market is one in which the big four control more than a third of the market, then over half of the Australian economy is excessively concentrated.

This doesn't of itself demonstrate that we have a problem with competition, but rarely do you see problems with competition arise in markets where there is not a concentration issue. Bullies aren't usually the scrawniest kids in the playground. Yet one of the questions is how we go about enforcing our competition laws to make sure consumers get a good deal. In the United States, at the moment, around 90 per cent of all antitrust cases are initiated by private litigants. Recognising the public value of those cases, the United States has a measure that allows for triple damages in such cases. In Australia the share of antitrust litigation brought by private individuals is, according to Caron Beaton-Wells of the University of Melbourne, only around 26 per cent.

Labor wants to change that. At the last election we took forward a policy known as Access to Justice, and I pay tribute to my shadow ministerial colleague Michelle Rowland for her work on developing that policy, as well as to the shadow minister for small business, Senator Katy Gallagher, and the shadow Treasurer, Chris Bowen, for their work on this policy. Labor's policy simply said that we want to allow private litigants who are bringing action under part IV of the Competition and Consumer Act to apply to a court at an early stage, seeking relief for potential adverse costs orders. Costs orders from courts can represent an unsurmountable barrier for many small businesses. They're willing to pay their own legal costs, but they're terrified of being bankrupted by the armada of QCs employed by the other side.

The European Union has called on jurisdictions in which costs follow the event to carefully review the appropriateness of this approach in competition cases. In the United Kingdom the Competition Appeal Tribunal has been granted the discretion to make any order it sees fit in relation to costs, as opposed to the usual rule that costs follow the event. Labor's measure ensures that we don't have a risk of frivolous or vexatious litigation by funding the small business ombudsman to vet small business applications for no adverse costs orders. This three-person section in the Small Business and Family Enterprise Ombudsman has been costed at around $500,000 per year. For that price, Australians get better enforcement of our competition laws and consumers get a better deal. The vexatious and frivolous cases won't go ahead, but we will see more actions by the small end of town, standing up for our competition laws.

I am disappointed not to be debating in this place the bill which has passed the Senate for Access to Justice, the Competition and Consumer Legislation Amendment (Small Business Access to Justice) Bill 2017. Labor's Access to Justice bill passed the Senate on 10 August 2017 by a vote of 36-22. At the time, we called on the government to bring that bill to this place so those who've said that they stand on the side of the little guys, such as the member for Dawson, would have the chance to vote on this legislation. Access to justice shouldn't be a partisan issue. I know that there are many on the other side of the House, particularly in the National Party, who in their hearts support Access to Justice. I hope we can bring the bill, which has passed the Senate, to the House and make it law. I am not the only one who hopes that. The Australian Small Business and Family Enterprise Ombudsman, Kate Carnell, said:

Access to justice is an important issue for small business operators. … The Senate bill allows Federal Court judges to waive liability for adverse costs to small business private litigants in cases related to the misuse of market power.
It gives small business operators confidence to proceed with legal action, knowing they will only be liable for their own costs.
This has the added benefit of filtering cases that might potentially be considered vexatious or unlikely to succeed, saving time and money for all involved.
Peter Strong, the CEO of COSBOA, said:

… access to justice for small business people has always been an issue for our members. The cost of going to court and facing highly paid barristers and expensive quarrels of lawyers is confronting when you know that to lose the case will bring exorbitant costs to cover the opposing sides legal expenses. We congratulate Bill Shorten and Labor on this initiative.
In March 2016, the Business Council of Australia chief executive, Jennifer Westacott, said:
The ALP policy announced today goes to the heart of the issue which is access to justice.

The organisations I have just quoted, COSBOA and the Business Council of Australia, don't agree on every matter in competition law, but they do agree that Labor's measure would make a positive difference.

You will hear occasionally from the other side of the House that an effects test might be a better way of tackling things. But the reason that then communications minister Malcolm Turnbull argued against an effects test in cabinet—alongside former Treasurer Joe Hockey, George Brandis, Andrew Robb and Senator Cormann—is that an effects test could potentially drive up consumer prices. It could increase uncertainty. It could stymie innovation and growth. As former Treasurer Peter Costello said:

If you take the view that competition is there for the consumer, which is what I believe is the fact, everything else will fit into place. That's why I’m against the so-called effects test, [which is] designed to protect competitors, particularly less efficient ones, from a competitive challenge.
Graeme Samuel, former ACCC chairman, said:

Under the Harper amendment, businesses would curb their competitive behaviour because of the legal risk. This would have drowned the commercial activity of big business in a sea of uncertainty.
